title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds a lack of reliable statistical information on franchise businesses despite their growing importance in the American marketplace. This information gap hinders objective investigations into franchise failures. Despite the lack of reliable statistics on franchise failures, a large amount of promotional material and articles present franchises as uniformly successful and low-risk. Inaccurate or misleading statistical information is often attributed to Federal Government agencies, leading franchisees to potentially suffer substantial losses without accurate information. The United States Department of Commerce's reports on franchise businesses prior to 1987 are often misused. Franchisees may face significant losses due to inaccurate or misleading information. The purpose of this Act is to provide comprehensive statistical information on franchising, enhance the reliability of information available to the public, and ensure prospective investors have the necessary information to make informed decisions. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. Franchise sellers must file their disclosure documents with the Commerce Department, including the most recent and restrictive version. Franchise sellers must annually file the most recent and restrictive version of their disclosure documents with the Commerce Department. The franchise agreement limits franchisees' rights and remedies. The Commerce Department requires annual filing of disclosure documents, which can be accessed by Congress and other agencies. Franchisors are prohibited from making false statements in advertisements or disclosures. It is illegal for franchisors to falsely claim that disclosure documents have been reviewed or approved by the Commerce Department or any other Federal agency. The Commerce Department is responsible for collecting and publishing data related to franchise agreements. The Commerce Department is tasked with collecting and publishing statistical information on franchise ownership and practices using disclosure documents as the main source. The Commerce Department collects statistical information on franchise ownership and practices using disclosure documents as the main source, establishing categories for data compilation and analysis. The Commerce Department collects statistical information on franchise businesses, including types, number of foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover, and franchise failures. They consult with various organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data compilation and analysis. The Commerce Department collects statistical information on franchise businesses, including types, number of foreign franchisors, annual growth, turnover, and franchise failures. They initiate periodic questionnaires of franchisors or franchisees to obtain statistical information to supplement disclosure documents. The Commerce Department collects statistical information on franchise businesses through periodic questionnaires of franchisors or franchisees to supplement disclosure documents. The Department will publish a report annually on this information. The Commerce Department will publish a report annually on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, as required by subsection (a) of this section. The report will be transmitted to Congress and made public through the Superintendent of Documents. The Commerce Department will publish an annual report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, as mandated by this section. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consult with the Federal Trade Commission to identify these businesses, and submit a report within 280 days of enactment. The Bureau of Census will work with the Federal Trade Commission to identify categories of statistical information for franchise businesses in the Business Census. A report on the most cost-effective and accurate data collection methods will be submitted to Congress within 280 days of enactment. SEC. 5. RULES, REGULATIONS AND FEES. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to make rules and regulations to implement the Act, including fees for filing requirements. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "advertisement," "disclosure document," and "franchise" in relation to commercial relationships created by contracts or agreements. The Act defines key terms related to commercial relationships created by contracts or agreements, including the term "franchise" which involves a continuing commercial relationship where a franchisor grants a franchisee the right to sell goods or services associated with a trademark. The franchise agreement involves the distribution of goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark or quality standards. The franchisee must adhere to quality standards set by the franchisor and operate under the franchisor's trademark. The franchisor also shares knowledge and expertise with the franchisee. The franchisor communicates knowledge, experience, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee, provides assistance in the franchisee's method of operation, and exercises significant controls over the franchisee's business operations. The franchisee must commit to these conditions to operate the franchise. The franchisee must make payment or commitment to the franchisor for goods, services, or subfranchise, based on representations made by the franchisor. The term "franchisee" refers to a person granted a franchise, while a "franchisor" is the one granting the franchise or subfranchise. A "subfranchise" is an agreement where a person pays a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
